ç”±äºåœ¨ä¸€èˆ¬æµè§ˆå™¨å’Œå®¢æˆ·ç«¯ä¸Šéƒ¨åˆ†è§†é¢‘æ— æ³•ç¡¬è½¬ç ï¼Œè€Œè½¯è§£åˆæåº¦æ¶ˆè€—CPUï¼Œåªæœ‰ä¸Šé¢å…¼å®¹è¡¨é‡ŒKodiå’Œ Jellyfin MPV Shimä¸¤ç§å®¢æˆ·ç«¯å¯ä»¥å®ç°å®Œç¾ç¡¬è§£ï¼Œä¸‹é¢åˆ†åˆ«ä»‹ç»ä¸¤ç§æ–¹æ³•ã€‚

Kodi

å®‰è£…æ–¹æ³•å‚è€ƒå‚è€ƒæ–‡æ¡£

The recommended install method is to use the official Jellyfin add-on repository. This allows for easy install of the Jellyfin for Kodi add-on, as well as automatically keeping the add-on up to date with the latest version. Any other Jellyfin related add-ons that may be built in the future will also be available in this repository.

The installation method for the repository varies depending on what kind of device youâ€™re using, outlined below.

General Use Devices (PCs and Tablets)
  1. Download the repository installer found here.
    • It will be saved as repository.jellyfin.kodi.zip
  2. Install the Jellyfin repository.
    • Open Kodi, go to the settings menu, and navigate to â€œAdd-On Browserâ€
    • Select â€œInstall from Zip Fileâ€
      • If prompted, enter settings and enable â€œUnknown Sourcesâ€, then go back to the Add-On Browser
    • Select the newly downloaded file and it will be installed
  3. Proceed to Install Jellyfin for Kodi Add-On
â€œEmbeddedâ€ Devices (Android TV, Firestick, and other TV Boxes)
  1. Open Kodi, go to the settings menu, and navigate to â€œFile managerâ€
    • Select â€œAdd sourceâ€
    • In the text box, enter https://kodi.jellyfin.org
    • Enter a name for the data source, such as â€œJellyfin Repoâ€ and select Ok
  2. From the settings menu, navigate to â€œAdd-On Browserâ€
    • Select â€œInstall from Zip Fileâ€
      • If prompted, enter settings and enable â€œUnknown Sourcesâ€, then go back to the Add-On Browser
    • Select the data source you just added
    • Install repository.jellyfin.kodi.zip
  3. Proceed to Install Jellyfin for Kodi Add-On
Install Jellyfin for Kodi Add-On

  1. Install Jellyfin for Kodi.

    • From within Kodi, navigate back to â€œAdd-On Browserâ€
    • Select â€œInstall from Repositoryâ€
    • Choose â€œKodi Jellyfin Addonsâ€, followed by â€œVideo Add-onsâ€
    • Select the Jellyfin add-on and choose install

  2. Within a few seconds you should be prompted for your server details.

    • If a Jellyfin server is detected on your local network, it will displayed in a dialog
    • If a Jellyfin server is not detected on your local network, select â€œManually Add Serverâ€. Enter your server info into the text field.
      • Enter the server name or IP address and the port number (default value is 8096)
        • Host: 192.168.1.10:8096
      • If using SSL and a reverse proxy, enter the full URL in the â€œHostâ€ field
        • Host: https://jellyfin.example.com
      • Note that if you have a baseurl set, you should append that value to the end of the host field.
        • Host: 192.168.0.10:8096/jellyfin
    • Select user account and input password, or select â€œManual Loginâ€ and fill in your user infomation

  3. Once youâ€™re succesfully authenticated with the server, youâ€™ll be asked about which mode youâ€™d like to use, Add-on vs Native, which are outlined below.

Add-on Mode

Add-on mode uses the Jellyfin server to translate media files from the filesystem to Kodi. This is the default setting for the add-on, and is sufficient for most use cases. It will work both on the local network and over the Internet through a reverse proxy or VPN connection. Providing network speed is sufficient, Kodi will direct play nearly all files and put little overhead on the Jellyfin server. Exceptions to this rule are files with 7.1 audio tracks and some 4k content, which will be transcoded by the server.

To use Add-on mode, simply choose â€œAdd-onâ€ at the dialog and proceed to Library Syncing

Native Mode

Native mode accesses your media files directly from the filesystem, bypassing the Jellyfin server during playback. Native mode needs more setup and configuration, but it can lead to better performance as everything will direct play no matter what format or encoding is used. It requires your media to be available to the device Kodi is running on over either NFS or Samba, and therefore should only be used on a LAN or over a VPN connection.

To use Native mode, first set up your libraries in Jellyfin with a remote path.

  1. In the Jellyfin server, navigate to the Libraries section of the admin dashboard.

    • Select an existing library (or create a new one)

    • Select the media folder

    • Enter the path to your network share in the â€œShared network folderâ€ textbox

    • Possible formats:

      • NFS

        • nfs://192.168.0.10:/path/to/media

      • Samba

        • Guest User - \\192.168.0.10\share_name

        • Custom User (Not Recommended) -

        

        - It's more secure to use the generic Guest mapping here and specify credentials from within Kodi

  1. Configure libraries in Kodi

    • Skip the initial library selection. We need to add file shares to Kodi first
    • Within Kodi, navigate to the settings menu and select â€œFile managerâ€
    • Select â€œAdd sourceâ€
    • Select â€œBrowseâ€ and â€œAdd network locationâ€
    • Create either a NFS or SMB location from the selection box and fill in the necessary information about your network share
    • Select your newly created location and choose â€œOkâ€
    • Give your media source a name and choose â€œOkâ€
    • Go to Add-Ons -> Jellyfin -> Manage Libraries -> Add Libraries

  2. Proceed to Library Syncing

Jellyfin MPV Shim

entry.title: åˆ©ç”¨WebDAVæŒ‚è½½OneDrive
entry.content:
edu.cnæ•™è‚²ç½‘é‚®ç®±å¯ä»¥ç”³è¯·åˆ°1Tå®¹é‡çš„Onedriveï¼Œç„¶è€Œåœ¨ä½¿ç”¨rcloneæŒ‚è½½Onedriveæ—¶ä¼šå‡ºç°Using application 'rclone' is currently not supported for your organization [YOUR_ORGANIZATION] because it is in an unmanaged stateé”™è¯¯ã€‚rcloneå®˜æ–¹å¦è¾Ÿè¹Šå¾„æä¾›äº†ä½¿ç”¨webDAVæŒ‚è½½è¿™ç±»Onedriveçš„æ–¹æ³•ã€‚

Error

access_denied (AADSTS65005)

This means that rclone canâ€™t use the OneDrive for Business API with your account. You canâ€™t do much about it, maybe write an email to your admins.

However, there are other ways to interact with your OneDrive account. Have a look at the webdav backend:

WebDAV

Paths are specified as remote:path

Paths may be as deep as required, eg remote:directory/subdirectory.

To configure the WebDAV remote you will need to have a URL for it, and a username and password. If you know what kind of system you are connecting to then rclone can enable extra features.

Here is an example of how to make a remote called remote. First run:

This will guide you through an interactive setup process:

Once configured you can then use rclone like this,

List directories in top level of your WebDAV

List all the files in your WebDAV

To copy a local directory to an WebDAV directory called backup

Sharepoint

Rclone can be used with Sharepoint provided by OneDrive for Business or Office365 Education Accounts. This feature is only needed for a few of these Accounts, mostly Office365 Education ones. These accounts are sometimes not verified by the domain owner github#1975

This means that these accounts canâ€™t be added using the official API (other Accounts should work with the â€œonedriveâ€ option). However, it is possible to access them using webdav.

To use a sharepoint remote with rclone, add it like this: First, you need to get your remoteâ€™s URL:

  • Go here to open your OneDrive or to sign in
  • Now take a look at your address bar, the URL should look like this: https://[YOUR-DOMAIN]-my.sharepoint.com/personal/[YOUR-EMAIL]/_layouts/15/onedrive.aspx

Youâ€™ll only need this URL upto the email address. After that, youâ€™ll most likely want to add â€œ/Documentsâ€. That subdirectory contains the actual data stored on your OneDrive.

Add the remote to rclone like this: Configure the url as https://[YOUR-DOMAIN]-my.sharepoint.com/personal/[YOUR-EMAIL]/Documents and use your normal account email and password for user and pass. If you have 2FA enabled, you have to generate an app password. Set the vendor to sharepoint.

Your config file should look like this:

Required Flags for SharePoint

As SharePoint does some special things with uploaded documents, you wonâ€™t be able to use the documents size or the documents hash to compare if a file has been changed since the upload / which file is newer.

For Rclone calls copying files (especially Office files such as .docx, .xlsx, etc.) from/to SharePoint (like copy, sync, etc.), you should append these flags to ensure Rclone uses the â€œLast Modifiedâ€ datetime property to compare your documents:

entry.title: ConvergenceWarningï¼šLiblinear failed to converge, increase the number of iterations
entry.content:
Q:

Running the code of linear binary pattern for Adrian. This program runs but gives the following warning:

A:

Normally when an optimization algorithm does not converge, it is usually because the problem is not well-conditioned, perhaps due to a poor scaling of the decision variables. There are a few things you can try.

  1. Normalize your training data so that the problem hopefully becomes more well conditioned, which in turn can speed up convergence. One possibility is to scale your data to 0 mean, unit standard deviation using Scikit-Learnâ€™s StandardScaler for an example. Note that you have to apply the StandardScaler fitted on the training data to the test data.
  2. Related to 1), make sure the other arguments such as regularization weight, C, is set appropriately.
  3. Set max_iter to a larger value. The default is 1000.

Comments

I am seeing that warning in this notebook: kaggle.com/ninovanhooff/svm-for-fraud-detection Note that it seems to be that all variables used for train and test are normalized I did not set any classifier parameters though, but unsure of what values of C to use. Should I set C based on my investigation of the coefficients? (See the bar plot in that notebook) â€“ Nino van Hooff Nov 15 â€˜18 at 16:32

Answer to my previous comment: As suggested by the scikit docs, I set dual to false. This removed the warning and seemed to have no influence on classification performance â€“ Nino van Hooff Nov 16 â€˜18 at 10:55

entry.title: Viewing Fortran Data Types in the Microsoft Debugger
entry.content:
view variables from modules in watch window

This topic applies to Fortran applications for Windows* only.

The following general suggestions apply to different types of Fortran data:

  • For scalar (nonarray) data, use the data tips (leave pointer on a variable name) feature or use the Locals window or a Watch window. IntelÂ® Fortran does not support the Autos window.
  • For single-dimension array data, derived-type data, record structure data, and COMPLEX data, use the Locals window or a Watch window.
  • For common blocks exported from a DLL, enter the name of the common block in a Watch window. You will be able to view the common block variables like any other structure.
  • By default, values of named constants (parameters) are not visible in the debugger. To make these visible, add the /debug-parameteres:used option or /debug-parameters:all option when compiling the sources.

For information on using Data Tips, the Locals window, or a Watch window, see Debugging the Squares Example Program.

The following sections apply to using a Watch window:

  • Specifying Array Sections
  • Specifying Module Variables
  • Specifying Format Specifiers

To display a Watch window:

  1. In the Debug menu, select Windows > Watch.
  2. In the submenu, click Watch 1, 2, 3, or 4.

Specifying Array Sections

You can specify array sections in a Watch window. For example, consider an array declared as:

You can specify the following statement in a Watch window to see the 2nd, 5th, and 8th elements:

When working with character arrays, this syntax may be combined with a substring specification. Consider the following array declaration:

You can specify the following statement in a Watch window to display the substring made up of character 3 through 8 of array elements 2 through 5:

This support is available for arrays of any type, including array pointers, assumed-shape, allocatable, and assumed-size arrays.

Any valid integer expression can be used when specifying lower bound, upper bound, or stride. If the lower bound is omitted, the array lower bound is used. If the upper bound is omitted, the array upper bound is used. For example, consider the following declaration:

To display:

  • Elements 1 through 8, specify foo(:8)
  • Elements 5 through 10, specify foo(5:)
  • All 10 elements, specify foo(:)

Specifying Module Variables

To view a module variable in a Watch window, specify the module name, followed by â€œ::â€, followed by the variable name.

For example, to watch variable â€œbarâ€ of module â€œfooâ€, specify the following expression:

Specifying Format Specifiers

You can use format specifiers in Watch windows to display variables in different data formats.

For example, given a REAL variable â€˜fooâ€™ in a program, it is now possible to see â€˜fooâ€™ in different floating point notation (by typing â€œfoo,fâ€ â€œfoo,gâ€ or â€œfoo,eâ€ in a Watch window) or as an integer (â€œfoo,iâ€ or â€œfoo,dâ€), a hexadecimal value (â€œfoo,xâ€), an an octal value (â€œfoo,oâ€), and so on.

You can change the display format of variables in a Watch window using the formatting symbols in the following table:

Symbol Format Value Displays
d,i signed decimal integer 0xF000F065 -268373915
o unsigned octal integer 0xF065 0170145
x,X Hexadecimal integer 61541 (decimal) #0000F065
f signed floating-point 3./2. 1.5000000
e signed scientific notation 3./2. 0.1500000E+01
g signed floating-point or signed scientific notation, whichever is shorter 3./2. 1.500000
c Single character 0x0065 â€˜eâ€™
s String 0x0012fde8 â€œHello worldâ€

To use a formatting symbol, type the variable name, followed by a comma and the appropriate symbol. For example, if var has a value of 0x0065, and you want to see the value in character form, type var,c in theName column on the tab of the Watch window. When you press ENTER, the character-format value appears:

You can use the formatting symbols shown in the following table to format the contents of memory locations:

Symbol Format Displays
ma 64 ASCII characters 0x0012ffac .4â€¦0â€¦â€.0W&â€¦â€¦.1W&.0.:W..1â€¦.â€..1.JO&.1.2..â€..1â€¦0yâ€¦.1
m 16 bytes in hexadecimal, followed by 16 ASCII characters 0x0012ffac B3 34 CB 00 84 30 94 80 FF 22 8A 30 57 26 00 00 .4â€¦0â€¦â€.0W&..
mb 16 bytes in hexadecimal, followed by 16 ASCII characters 0x0012ffac B3 34 CB 00 84 30 94 80 FF 22 8A 30 57 26 00 00 .4â€¦0â€¦â€.0W&..
mw 8 words 0x0012ffac 34B3 00CB 3084 8094 22FF 308A 2657 0000
md 4 doublewords 0x0012ffac 00CB34B3 80943084 308A22FF 00002657

With the memory location formatting symbols, you can type any value or expression that evaluates to a location.

A formatting character can also follow an expression:

NOTE

You can apply formatting symbols to structures, arrays, pointers, and objects as unexpanded variables only. If you expand the variable, the specified formatting affects all members. You cannot apply formatting symbols to individual members.

entry.title: Configuration forpy on Windows with Intel visual fortran complier
entry.content:
forpy is a library to use Python features in Fortran (â€œembedding Python in Fortranâ€) as this Link, configuration of it on Visual Studio, Intel Visual Fortran compiler on Windows 10 follows steps as:

Steps

  1. switch debug to x64 mode if anaconda is x64
  2. tools-settings-Intel Composer XE-Visual Fortran-Compilers-x64
    add â€œC:\ProgramData\Anaconda3\includeâ€ to Includes
    add â€œC:\ProgramData\Anaconda3\libsâ€ to Libraries
    where â€œC:\ProgramData\Anaconda3\â€ is root path of python.exe
  3. project properties-Fortran-Preprocessor-Preprocess Source File Yes(/fpp)
    Linker-Input-Additional Dependencies python36.lib (depends on libs)
  4. If step 2 is skipped, â€œincludeâ€ path to Fortran-General-Additional Include Directories and â€œlibsâ€ path to Linker-General-Additional Library Directories

Notice:

If I set PYTHONHOME variable on Windows (my anaconda version 3.6.3) an error like â€œFatal Python error: Py_Initialize: unable to load the file system codec ModuleNotFoundError: No module named â€˜encodingsâ€™ â€œ will be induced like https://bugs.python.org/issue27054. â€œintro_to_forpyâ€ works well without PYTHONHOME.

update:

works with PYTHONHOME too. Configure PYTHONHOME to â€œC:\ProgramData\Anaconda3\â€ at first then open VS compiler

use errcheck to check ierror and print error messages.

if ierror = -1 and show message about â€œImportError: DLL load failed: æ‰¾ä¸åˆ°æŒ‡å®šçš„æ¨¡å—â€ when use import_py to import some python module, reinstall this module with pip may solve this problem.

entry.title: æœ‰é™å…ƒæ³•ã€æœ‰é™å·®åˆ†æ³•å’Œæœ‰é™ä½“ç§¯æ³•çš„åŒºåˆ«ï¼ˆè½¬è½½ï¼‰
entry.content:
FDMï¼ŒFVMå’ŒFEMçš„æ¦‚å¿µå’ŒåŒºåˆ«ã€‚

æœ‰é™å·®åˆ†æ–¹æ³•(FDM)**æ˜¯è®¡ç®—æœºæ•°å€¼æ¨¡æ‹Ÿæœ€æ—©é‡‡ç”¨çš„æ–¹æ³•ï¼Œè‡³ä»Šä»è¢«å¹¿æ³›è¿ç”¨ã€‚è¯¥æ–¹æ³•å°†æ±‚è§£åŸŸåˆ’åˆ†ä¸ºå·®åˆ†ç½‘æ ¼ï¼Œç”¨æœ‰é™ä¸ªç½‘æ ¼èŠ‚ç‚¹ä»£æ›¿è¿ç»­çš„æ±‚è§£åŸŸã€‚æœ‰é™å·®åˆ†æ³•ä»¥Taylorçº§æ•°å±•å¼€ç­‰æ–¹æ³•ï¼ŒæŠŠæ§åˆ¶æ–¹ç¨‹ä¸­çš„å¯¼æ•°ç”¨ç½‘æ ¼èŠ‚ç‚¹ä¸Šçš„å‡½æ•°å€¼çš„å·®å•†ä»£æ›¿è¿›è¡Œç¦»æ•£ï¼Œä»è€Œå»ºç«‹ä»¥ç½‘æ ¼èŠ‚ç‚¹ä¸Šçš„å€¼ä¸ºæœªçŸ¥æ•°çš„ä»£æ•°æ–¹ç¨‹ç»„ã€‚è¯¥æ–¹æ³•æ˜¯ä¸€ç§ç›´æ¥å°†å¾®åˆ†é—®é¢˜å˜ä¸ºä»£æ•°é—®é¢˜çš„è¿‘ä¼¼æ•°å€¼è§£æ³•ï¼Œæ•°å­¦æ¦‚å¿µç›´è§‚ï¼Œè¡¨è¾¾ç®€å•ï¼Œæ˜¯å‘å±•è¾ƒæ—©ä¸”æ¯”è¾ƒæˆç†Ÿçš„æ•°å€¼æ–¹æ³•ã€‚

å¯¹äºæœ‰é™å·®åˆ†æ ¼å¼ï¼Œä»æ ¼å¼çš„ç²¾åº¦æ¥åˆ’åˆ†ï¼Œæœ‰ä¸€é˜¶æ ¼å¼ã€äºŒé˜¶æ ¼å¼å’Œé«˜é˜¶æ ¼å¼ã€‚ä»å·®åˆ†çš„ç©ºé—´å½¢å¼æ¥è€ƒè™‘ï¼Œå¯åˆ†ä¸ºä¸­å¿ƒæ ¼å¼å’Œé€†é£æ ¼å¼ã€‚è€ƒè™‘æ—¶é—´å› å­çš„å½±å“ï¼Œå·®åˆ†æ ¼å¼è¿˜å¯ä»¥åˆ†ä¸ºæ˜¾æ ¼å¼ã€éšæ ¼å¼ã€æ˜¾éšäº¤æ›¿æ ¼å¼ç­‰ã€‚ç›®å‰å¸¸è§çš„å·®åˆ†æ ¼å¼ï¼Œä¸»è¦æ˜¯ä¸Šè¿°å‡ ç§å½¢å¼çš„ç»„åˆï¼Œä¸åŒçš„ç»„åˆæ„æˆä¸åŒçš„å·®åˆ†æ ¼å¼ã€‚å·®åˆ†æ–¹æ³•ä¸»è¦é€‚ç”¨äºæœ‰ç»“æ„ç½‘æ ¼ï¼Œç½‘æ ¼çš„æ­¥é•¿ä¸€èˆ¬æ ¹æ®å®é™…åœ°å½¢çš„æƒ…å†µå’ŒæŸ¯æœ—ç¨³å®šæ¡ä»¶æ¥å†³å®šã€‚

æ„é€ å·®åˆ†çš„æ–¹æ³•æœ‰å¤šç§å½¢å¼ï¼Œç›®å‰ä¸»è¦é‡‡ç”¨çš„æ˜¯æ³°å‹’çº§æ•°å±•å¼€æ–¹æ³•ã€‚å…¶åŸºæœ¬çš„å·®åˆ†è¡¨è¾¾å¼ä¸»è¦æœ‰ä¸‰ç§å½¢å¼ï¼šä¸€é˜¶å‘å‰å·®åˆ†ã€ä¸€é˜¶å‘åå·®åˆ†ã€ä¸€é˜¶ä¸­å¿ƒå·®åˆ†å’ŒäºŒé˜¶ä¸­å¿ƒå·®åˆ†ç­‰ï¼Œå…¶ä¸­å‰ä¸¤ç§æ ¼å¼ä¸ºä¸€é˜¶è®¡ç®—ç²¾åº¦ï¼Œåä¸¤ç§æ ¼å¼ä¸ºäºŒé˜¶è®¡ç®—ç²¾åº¦ã€‚é€šè¿‡å¯¹æ—¶é—´å’Œç©ºé—´è¿™å‡ ç§ä¸åŒå·®åˆ†æ ¼å¼çš„ç»„åˆï¼Œå¯ä»¥ç»„åˆæˆä¸åŒçš„å·®åˆ†è®¡ç®—æ ¼å¼ã€‚

entry.title: Use Gmsh and SU2 to simulate 2D compressor cascade
entry.content:
This article describle simulation of 2D compressor cascade with Gmsh for grid generation and SU2 for flowfield.

Thanks Nathan Ricksâ€™ help!**

Draft block topological structure

Curve1 - LE circle, Curve2 - suction surface, Curve3 - TE circle, Curve4 - pressure surface, Curve5,6,7,8 - transition curve between dense and sparse nodes. All these curves build the airfoil line loop.

The inlet, outlet and two periodic boundaries construct another line loop. The two line loops construct computational domain.

Need to notice:

The direction of the curves used for line loop;

The index of Line should be correspond to the physical curve marker

Generation of unstructured mesh by Gmsh

Python script

Generation and check with GUI

Gmsh -2 cascade_airfoil.geo -o airfoil.su2

check the label and direction of curves carefully!

SU2 numerical simulation

Preprocessing periodic boundary by SU2_MSH

Use SU2_MSH to generate the periodic .su2 mesh, optional to modify the MESH_OUT_FILENAME in .cfg file or the default meshout.su2 will be generated.

Notice that the periodic distance in .cfg file should be correspond to gmsh!!

SU2_MSH xxx.cfg

If the periodic boundaries were specified with wrong label, SU2_MSH will give warning as follow:

Now in the work directory three files are generated: periodic_orignianl.dat, periodic_halo.dat (Tecplot readable) and meshout.su2(if MESH_OUT_FILENAME unchanged).

mesh original

mesh halo

Run SU2_CFD

Sequential Mode

SU2_CFD xxx.cfg

Parallel Mode

parallel_computation.py -n 8 -f xxx.cfg

Use tail command to monitor the real-time result in history.dat

tail -f history.dat

Post-processing

Use tecplot to show the convergence history and flow field details.

Notes

  • In Gmsh, use Periodic Curve â€˜{per1 index} = {per2 index} translate {0,delta_y,0}â€™ to specify the periodic boundary.

  • Use â€˜python parallel_computation.py [options]â€™ to run parallel case instead of â€˜mpirunâ€™ or solution â€˜flow.datâ€™ will miss.

  • su2 cfg AOA is invalid if specify inlet boundary flow direction.

  • Use SU2_MSH to check the .su2 mesh before running SU2_CFD. Modify the MESH_OUT_FILENAME in .cfg file to custom name, then command line /SU2_MSH xxx.cfg

å­¦ä¹ ICEM CFDç»˜åˆ¶2Då¹³é¢å¶æ …ç½‘æ ¼å¿ƒå¾—ã€‚

1ã€å‡†å¤‡å¶å‹æ•°æ®æ–‡ä»¶ï¼Œæ ¼å¼å¦‚ä¸‹ï¼Œç¬¬ä¸€è¡Œè¡¨ç¤ºæ¯æ¡çº¿æœ‰141ä¸ªç‚¹ï¼Œæœ‰ä¸¤æ¡çº¿ï¼Œæ¥ä¸‹æ¥æ˜¯å„ç‚¹çš„XYZåæ ‡ï¼Œå¶å‹åæ ‡å†åŠ ä¸€åˆ—é›¶ã€‚æ³¨æ„Fluenté»˜è®¤2Då¹³é¢æ˜¯XYå¹³é¢ï¼Œéœ€è¦Zåæ ‡ç½®é›¶ï¼Œä¸èƒ½å°†Xæˆ–Yåæ ‡ç½®é›¶ï¼›


2ã€è½½å…¥æ ¼å¼åŒ–å‡ ä½•æ–‡ä»¶ï¼Œæ³¨æ„è°ƒæ•´å…¬å·®é¿å…å‰åç¼˜åŠå¾„å°äºå…¬å·®è¢«æŠ¹æ‰ï¼›

3ã€è½½å…¥å¶å‹åï¼Œé€šè¿‡Geometryé€‰é¡¹å¡ä¸‹çš„å·¥å…·è¿›è¡Œä¿®æ”¹ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨ä¸­çº¿å·¥å…·(Create midline)å¯¹å¸å‹åŠ›é¢ç”Ÿæˆä¸­å¼§çº¿ï¼Œä¸Šä¸‹å¹³ç§»ä¸­å¼§çº¿ä¸€ä¸ªæ …è·å½¢æˆå¶æ …é€šé“ã€‚é€šé“ä¸Šæ¸¸ç«¯ç‚¹å‘å·¦ä¸‹æ–¹å‘å»¶ç”³ä¸€ä¸ªå¼¦é•¿å·¦å³å½¢æˆè¿›å£æ®µï¼Œå‡ºå£æ®µåŒç†ã€‚ä½¿ç”¨ç«¯ç‚¹å·¥å…·(Curve ends)ç”»å‡ºç«¯ç‚¹ï¼›


4ã€ç‚¹å‡»Blockingå·¥å…·æ ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨2DPlaneråˆå§‹åŒ–Blockï¼Œå¹¶å°†Blockå¯¹åº”çš„ç‚¹å’Œè¾¹çº¿å…³è”(Associate)è‡³å‡ ä½•ï¼Œæ­¤æ—¶éœ€è¦å°†å·¦è¾¹æ Geometryçš„Pointså’ŒCurvesï¼ŒBlockingçš„Edgeså’ŒVerticeså‹¾ä¸Šã€‚

snapä¼˜ç‚¹ï¼šThe snap is nice for getting up and running quickly with minimal space, and will work great if youâ€™re happy not messing with it. Since itâ€™s a snap you also get the benefit of automatic updates and the ability to rollback without worrying about needing to take a snapshot, etc.

#ç¿»è¯‘ï¼šsnapå®‰è£…å¿«æ·ï¼Œå‚»ç“œå¼ä¸€é”®å®‰è£…ï¼Œå‡ åˆ†é’Ÿå†…æå®šã€‚åŒæ—¶ï¼Œsnapæ”¯æŒè‡ªåŠ¨å‡çº§ã€å›æ»šç­‰ï¼Œä½ æ— éœ€ä½¿ç”¨å¤æ‚çš„å‘½ä»¤å·¥å…·ã€‚

snapç¼ºç‚¹ï¼šHowever, the snap is very opinionated. Donâ€™t want to use Apache? Sorry, the snap uses it. Donâ€™t want to use MySQL? Sorry, MariaDB does not run on ARM. Something other than PHP 7.0.15? We picked the version we feel gives the best results. In other words, itâ€™s not very tinker-friendly. We donâ€™t do this to be mean, we do this so that we can reliably update it without your needing to worry about it.

#ç¿»è¯‘ï¼šsnapä¸èƒ½è‡ªå®šä¹‰ï¼Œåªèƒ½ä½¿ç”¨snapæ—¢å®šçš„MysqLã€apacheã€PHPç­‰ã€‚ä¸è¿‡ï¼Œè¿™æ ·çš„å¥½å¤„å°±æ˜¯ç»è¿‡å®˜æ–¹æµ‹è¯•è¿‡çš„è¿è¡Œç¨³å®šä¸”æœ‰åˆ©äºåæœŸè‡ªåŠ¨å‡çº§ã€‚

VPSæ‰‹åŠ¨å®‰è£…ä¼˜ç¼ºç‚¹ï¼šThe VM is much more flexible. Itâ€™s a full version of Ubuntu server edition, allowing you to tweak whatever you need and it comes with many apps which are not that easy to configure for inexperienced administrators. This of course makes it larger. Youâ€™ll also need to make sure you maintain it and keep the OS up-to-date. Since itâ€™s virtualized you can assign disk, CPU, memory, and network quotas to it (youâ€™d need to install the snap in an lxc container or a VM to get the same abilities).
